newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Calvo says Mexican peso not overvalued.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Calvo says Mexican peso not overvalued.

text.p: Economist Guillermo Calvo said on Friday he believed the Mexican peso is not overvalued, but urged policymakers to restructure the country's short-term domestic debt.

"I see no indication of overvaluation," the University of Maryland economist, who predicted Mexico's 1994 financial crisis, said in an interview with Reuters. "I don't see anything preventing the peso, if it is really undervalued or overvalued, from moving to the right equilibrium."

Calvo said the Mexican authorities should not abandon monetary discipline to allow peso depreciation because such a tactic could spook the financial markets. The markets still recall in horror the surprise devaluation of December 1994.
"My fear is that if you start tampering around with the peso, you may lose control of the peso," Calvo said.
In the wake of recent comments by U.S. economist Rudiger Dornbusch, the peso has lost ground in recent weeks, ending close to one full year of relative stability.
Dornbusch said the peso's real appreciation was leading to an overvaluation that repeated Mexico's mistakes of 1994.

"If the markets for any reason read any active policy a la Dornbusch as an indication that the central bank is abandoning monetary discipline, then there could be a stampede away from pesos and a devaluation," Calvo said. "You could generate a crisis."

On Friday, the Mexican currency dropped 5.3 centavos to 7.9150/7.9250 pesos per dollar amid jitters over the upcoming "pacto," an agreement on economic measures hammered out by the government, business and labor leaders.
In the aftermath to the peso's move, overnight Cetes rates opened 125 basis points higher but later fell back.
The rise in Cetes rates illustrated the main problem facing Mexican policymakers -- the potential for instability if investors lose confidence, Calvo said.

"The instability has not disappeared because Mexico still has a large mass of short term debt," Calvo said "I don't think it is major. They have the wherewithal and the instruments to control it, but not 100 percent."

Should investors lose confidence for any reason, the $7.0 to $8.0 billion Cetes market could rapidly challenge Mexican policymakers. To head off any hint of uncertainty, authorities should replace short-term Cetes debt with longer-term obligations from the international market, Calvo said.
"What they should do is restructure the domestic debt into longer-term instruments," the Argentine economist said. "Ideally they should fund the instruments outside the country."
Currently, the country does not face a crisis of confidence, and has dramatically improved its debt profile by redeeming about $28 billion of short-term dollar-indexed Tesobonos last year.
The strategy to stem peso instability by pushing Cetes rates higher has proved highly effective, but may be difficult to sustain over the long haul, Calvo said.
The use of higher interest rates to control the peso over a long period would both weigh on the economy and give troubling indications that the exchange rate is not at equilibrium, Calvo said.

"In the short-run, they are doing what they ought to do," Calvo said. "In order to be able to lower interest rates, they have to restructure. Once they restructure the debt, then they will be able to afford to intervene without causing instability."
